children.text: Last year, I took the opportunity of International Women's Day (and yes, Bex, I do remember our conversation about the slight dodgy roots of the ‚Äúofficial‚Äù version of it‚Ä¶) to recommend six journalists you should follow on Twitter to mark the day.

metadata.title: Six journalists you should follow on International Women‚Äôs Day
metadata.description: Get more smart female voices in your Twitter timeline.
metadata.author: Adam Tinworth

children.text: It's time to do it again.
Why's this a day late, Adam?

I was going to post this yesterday, on the actual International Women's Day. But as I looked at social media, I could see more men talking about women than women talking about themselves. So I decided to shut the hell up and let women speak yesterday, and postpone my piece until today.
So, here it is: my second annual list of six women whom you should follow (just after) International Women's Day.
They must work in or around journalism.
I must find what they are doing genuinely inspiring or interesting
They must have fewer Twitter followers than me.
[NEW] No more than two colleagues or two former students

children.calloutText: Another change from last year: I'm linking to more than one social profile. Just linking to Twitter feel less valuable than it did a year ago. Thanks, Mr Musk!

children.text: Vera is the Director of Programmes & Impact at the
. The work the organisation is doing is great and much needed, and Vera does a great job of promoting it. In particular, I miss their
, which I haven't managed to get to in person since before the pandemic. Next time‚Ä¶
She's a low volume tweeter, but every Tweet is useful. For example:

urls.title: The barriers faced by second-language English journalists
urls.description: I'm sick of lying to young foreign journalists who ask me for advice. Because the only honest reply is: "Can you pass as a native speaker?"

tweets.text:
"I'm sick of lying to young foreign journalists who ask me for advice. Because the honest reply is 'Can you pass as a native English speaker?'"

My latest newsletter on how diversity in media rarely extends to language & to second-language English voices.

https://t.co/dYdEWtgVpA

children.text: How the ever-living f**k does Charlotte have fewer followers than me?
, knows her Mac tech and certainly knows way more about sport than I do. C'mon, she's an essential follow, and her newsletter is an essential subscribe.

children.text: This year, I've picked two graduates from two different generations of the

If you want to know why, after a decade of visiting lecturing at City, I finally went on staff part time this year, well, it's because of people like Emily. Nothing gives me greater pleasure than seeing students grow, find their confidence and go on to
careers. And that's just what Emily has done.
As Head of Audience and Product Manager at
, she leads a talented team of engagement pros. Like many professionals in this space, she doesn't tweet often, but it's worth following her for when she does.

children.text: Shamefully, she still has under 200 followers. Fix that, my friends.
People who have the misfortune of working with me at City. And I mean misfortune. The last visiting lecturer who taught with me

Full disclosure: Mel is my boss (for half the week, at least. I'm my own boss the other half). But she has the unenviable task of wrangling a whole department full of journalism academics, two groups whom managing must be like herding cats at best of times, and so are probably even worse when combined‚Ä¶.
And yet, she keeps her research going at the same time. A bit like
from last year, I wonder HOW DOES SHE DO IT?

of journalism.co.uk looks into the sheer volume of threats and harassment that female journalists face in their work.

metadata.title: Three quarters of women journalists experience threat to their safety
metadata.description: A first-of-its-kind survey of women working in the media revealed how threats, harassment and violence impact their careers and mental health
metadata.author: Marcela Kunova

metadata.title: Online abuse toll means fifth of women journalists considered leaving industry
metadata.description: A fifth of 403 women respondents to a survey by Reach/Women in Journalism said they had considered leaving journalism as a result of abuse.
metadata.author: Charlotte Tobitt

children.text: My students at City have been doing some great IWD work:

metadata.title: Women‚Äôs experiences in journalism: heads of audience
metadata.description: On this Women‚Äôs International Day, we‚Äôve spoken to female digital journalists about their experience working in the newsroom.
metadata.author: Vlada Goriacheva

metadata.title: The Gender Pay Gap at British Newspapers - Interhacktives
metadata.description: Inspired by Twitter‚Äôs Gender Pay Gap Bot, we take a look at pay gap at British newspapers this International Women‚Äôs Day.
metadata.author: Katie Jones

metadata.title: 7 female data journalists to look our for - Interhacktives
metadata.description: On this International Women‚Äôs Day, these 7 female data journalists are making waves with their incredible work
metadata.author: Hyein Jung

children.text: And, of course, the good folks at the Reuters Institute had some great research:

metadata.title: Women and leadership in the news media 2023: evidence from 12 markets
metadata.description: In this factsheet we analyse the gender breakdown of top editors in a sample of 240 major news outlets in 12 different markets.
metadata.author: Dr Kirsten Eddy
metadata.publisher: Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism
